text: HIV-1 <extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> leads to inhibition or activation of T cells depending on its intracellular localization .
<extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> of primate lentiviruses is required for viremia and progression to AIDS in monkeys .
Negative , positive , and no effects of <extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have also been reported on viral replication in cells .
To reconcile these observations , we expressed a hybrid CD8 - <extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein in Jurkat cells .
Two opposite phenotypes were found , which depended on the intracellular localization of <extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Expressed in the cytoplasm or on the cell surface , the chimera inhibited or activated early signaling events from the T cell antigen receptor .

Activated Jurkat cells died by apoptosis , and only cells with mutated <extra_id_0> nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> genes expressing truncated <extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> s survived , which rendered <extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> nonfunctional .
These mutations paralleled those in other viral strains passaged in vitro .

Not only do these positional effects of <extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> reconcile diverse phenotypes of <extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and suggest a role for its N-terminal myristylation , but they also explain effects of <extra_id_0> Nef <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in HIV infection and progression to AIDS .
